comments.commentBody: You can easily block banner ads with AdBlock Plus (for Firefox) and/or AdAway (For Android). I'm not sure about iOS, but I highly suspect that there are similar solutions for said platform.

There are plenty of ways to arrange things so that defined benefit pension benefit plans could be portable across employers & a working career.

Since making those arrangements would require adroit elected officials actively engaged in governance, along with political will, the odds for such a development in the US are very, very, very long

Well stated, MS. I'll bet that 90%+ of the people reading this NY Times article are being tracked with cookies and LSO's (local shared objects). Simple add-on plugins can be utilized to curtail this tracking to a very large extent, but most people don't bother to lean about and implement such solutions.

The big flaw in deep linking (like everything else on the web) is SECURITY.

Do you really want to share things across applications when some of those things are what you want to keep secure?
This is just one more tool marketers will use to hound us even more mercilessly.

Law-

I agree. Matter with mass will never travel faster than the speed of light, in the traditional sense of concept.

However, I am not willing to say with such conviction that it will be forever impossible for matter to be moved from point A to B faster than it would take light to travel the intervening distance between the two points. We know experimentally that this happens with information that is shared between entangled pairs; I think there are great depths to be plumbed when it comes to this phenomenon (as your comment seems to recognize).

This is purely non-scientific conjecture, but I wonder if there may be some kind of equivalence between information and matter, echoing the equivalence between matter and energy. Perhaps they are all equivalent terms in an equation we haven't fully determined how to express.

That said, your point regarding generation ships is well taken, and it is enticing idea.

You are of course entitled to your opinion, but in my entire life, I haven't encountered many statements that I disagree with more fundamentally than your sentiment, particularly insofar as it comes in response to the discovery of 8 potentially Earthlike exoplanets.

Maybe you have better wallpaper than me.
Your wallpaper comment now comes into clearer focus...

Let's keep our cosmic criteria for life-capable planets open. Having read about the possibility of water oceans on Jupiter's moon Europa (due to gravitational forces) is just one example of an environment that could facilitate the formation of living organisms well outside the habitable zone where Earth is located. Planets in the so-called "Goldilocks" zone is but one way to define where life can come into being and evolve. What really matters are temperate environments where energy gradients (from solar, heat, or kinetic sources) are moderate and convertible into metabolic processes.

Carbon can form stable, complex molecules unlike any other element. Carbon is also relatively common. That doesn't mean that silicon life doesn't exist, but odds are higher that carbon is the foundation of most life. That doesn't mean they'll look like anything on Earth, though.
It's far easier to cool down Venus than to provide an atmosohere and then heat up Mars.

comments.userLocation: I wish I was in Dixie...
comments.commentBody:
As for your first paragraph, I could take about why it is better for an educated elite to run the country rather than a fickle mob, but at some point you would probably say what I would say about the United States, "Wrong elite." As our political ideologies must be nearly polar by your opinion of Southern ideas such as free trade (they needed free trade to sell their cotton of course) and small government (they had a clause in their Constitution that would have prevented Obamacare easily). The people were so moved by the Southern elite however, that they marched into battle for their freedom; whether that would have been the end result is up in the air considering the history of revolutions and rebellions not yielding freedom.

Your second paragraph is good, and I have studied enough to answer your questions. Sorry it took me so long to find them. :) First of all, Davis was begging the Union for peace. Lincoln, however, was the one who brought up war in his own inaugural address if memory serves. As for Fort Sumter, that had me confused until I discovered a few details left out. As the Southern states declared their independence they had began sending Federal troops packing. Forts all over the South were cleared without a single drop of blood. When Lincoln saw what was going on, he began meddling with the political end in South Carolina, making it known that he was resupplying a fort that was on Confederate soil so they could have an extended stay. They sent an envoy to the..

Science has provided evidence. A staggering amount of it. At present, science has not PROVED it by direct observation, but there is a convincing syllogism. Science has thoroughly established that life on Earth arose from chemical processes requiring certain elements-a certain range of temperatures, a certain density of atmosphere, a certain level of solar radiation (and magnetic protection), and, of course, certain actual elements. And it arose, it appears, pretty much as soon (in geological terms-and certainly in cosmological) as it possibly could. So early, and in such dire circumstances, in fact, that it appears to be a great statistical likelihood, once you have a planet like Earth.

Science has also established observationally that planets are exceedingly common in our galaxy, something already predicted by the physical laws. And now, science has established that some of these planets are Earth-like in position and density. Soon, we'll be able to figure out how many are Earth-like in composition and atmosphere, but you can already work out a ballpark statistically that puts the number Earth-like (within the range the article describes) in our galaxy in the millions.

So: Earth was highly likely to give rise to life; there are many Earths in the universe: There is life elsewhere in the universe.

Again, we haven't observed it (just as, until the past few decades, we hadn't observed extrasolar planets), but the odds that it's true are vastly better than 50/50.
the Baby boomers' life span is extremely limited. every 100 years, all new people.
This American's television, and I am fortunate to have one, is going to remain turned off so that none of these political people are in view of one's eyes.

Mr. Figliozzi,
At this stage and for the longest time, it does appear that many of us wish to be fooled.

Does Boehner turn more orange with every additional Republican elected?  I thought my television's color settings had gone off.  It's not surprising that the Speaker would call on the President to "cooperate", though his real meaning was "capitulate".  Not surprising, but supremely hypocritical.  If you thought it was bad before, just watch the next two years.  It will test Lincoln's theory that one cannot fool all of the people all of the time.

Putting aside the assumption that life can only arise and become complex as it did on Earth (but not the thing about the comets-still in high debate and anyway not very improbable at all-or the dinosaurs-why on Earth (or Wherever) would a civilization-building species someplace else in the universe need an asteroid to kill of the dinosaurs), you're confusing the "highly improbable" with "probably didn't happen."

Pick any random mass of interstellar dust beginning to do its thing and no, you're probably not going to get life out of it, not ever, at least not life as we know it. But take one hundred billion masses of interstellar dust... Let's say it's worse than the powerball that any stellar system will contain life. Let's say it's 1 in 1,000,000,000. That's 100 planets inhabited by civilization-building species.

But if that's not good enough, add some zeroes. The observable universe has so many stellar systems I won't number them without superscript.

We are probably not alone.

I am in awe at the immensity of the universe. We live on a planet that is just a tiny 'dot' in this unimaginable vastness.

See how small we are at this site.
http://www.ba-bamail.com/content_13054/The_True_Scale_of_the_Universe.aspx

And yet we are, as 'humans' on this tiny, minuscule, planet, able study, understand and speculate on this matter, scientifically. With the rigorous standards (unlike religion) requires.

To me that is simply, stupendously and awesomely amazing.

The final nail? Hardly. There is plenty of evidence to support the theory of evolution; has any of it served as the "final nail"? If we do find evidence that life exists elsewhere then that will simply service as yet another reason for liberals and conservatives to quarrel over.
a lot more than 600 years. some Ancient Greeks knew that we revolve around the sun. they also surmised the size of the earth.

Biochemists believe Carbon to be the most promising basis for life on any planet due its ability to form long chains with itself (e.g handy molecules like proteins and DNA). Unfortuntately for "life" not based on electricity, Silicon doesn't quite cut it.

What's interesting to think about is how likely it is that life that has emerged on planets similar to ours might look just like forms we have on the Earth at this very moment.

"And yet we still do not have a clue that we are not alone."

Really? I wonder what would happen if an equivalent amount of money spent on all this gadgetry were spent attempting to engage in meaningful communication with some of the numerous aliens who routinely visit our little rocky planet. Bet you they'd have a lot to tell us.
sorry, I don't believe a word of it. probability? feh.
They would be shunned and incur all sorts of problems, same as any scab or company man in a workplace with strong solidarity.

Actually, this is also how the "blue wall of silence" works, but in reverse.  That is, if a cop does something "bad," it is extremely difficult for others (who continue to do "good") to openly say anything, because they have to continue to work with the "bad" cop.  It is not as if EVERY cop - most of whom are just regular Joes and Janes who do a job and want to get home alive to their families - condones the behavior of the "bad apples."  It is that they are "stuck."

The Police need to grow up and do their job or quit. If they hate New Yorkers and the Mayor they elected why take our tax money to serve us? Why not just stay in Staten Island, Jersey or Long Island and leave us New Yorkers alone.

How does this work exactly. If partner cops disagree-- one wants to do the job as assigned, and the other doesn't -- does one try to intimidate the other?  Is this reinforced by people further up the command chain? How does a responsible cop act responsibly without incurring the wrath of those around him who might want to continue the work stoppage. Bratton better get hold of his force, or it will rot from the inside out.

I ,too remember the early space program (and earlier than that). It really is amazing what we have discovered and how we have expanded our view of the universe. Instead of actually having to visit, ala the explorers of the 15th century, we can do it from the comfort of home sitting at a keyboard -- and we can all make the trip!

Being a baby boomer who grew up with the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs the last few years have been more than amazing. Lately it seems to be an elongated version of Moore's Law describing increasing speed in computer processers.

Consider that centuries ago the earth was flat and the sun rotated around us. Slowly we have gotten a better grasp of what the universe is like. But lately its more like a roller coaster ride at the speed of new announcements. To be able to land on object on a comet, really.

I really love articles like this, it shows me that mankind can do more than just fight wars and subjugate people. This is really like the arts an example of our highest aspirations.
that Jesus quote, the mansions were a metaphor.
